quoteFirst: This ridge consists of a series of rocks, which form the chain of mountains which commences north of Lake Erie, stretches eastward to the Niagara river, confines it, and forms its falls; then continues its course, and forms the different falls which are north of Lake Ontario, and is at length lost in the neighbourhood of the Hudson. The canal runs a distance through sombre forests, when they reached Lockport on the 20th of August, about
quoteLast: in the morning. At this place the canal is carried over the ridge by five large locks, through which the water is raised to the height of seventy-six feet.
title:
Alida; or, Miscellaneous Sketches of Incidents During the Late American War.

author: Comfield, Amelia Stratton, 1785?-

quoteFirst: Both were well mounted, and yet, contrary to his wont, Cellini did not urge his horse. It was evident that he did not wish to enter Paris before a certain hour, and it was
quoteLast: in the evening when he alighted at Rue de la Harpe.

quoteLast: . Mr. Harding looked down at them and put his hand on one little fellow’s head.

quoteFirst: mile, South-West a quarter of a mile, East by South a quarter of a mile, veered to West-North-West a quarter of a mile, South-West one eighth of a mile, East-South-East one quarter of a mile, East one sixth of a mile, South-South-West one twelfth of a mile, East-South-East one eighth of a mile, North-East by East one third of a mile, East by North one twelfth of a mile, North-East by East one third of a mile, East one sixteenth of a mile, South-East one twelfth of a mile, North-East by East one twelfth of a mile, East one eighth of a mile, and East-South-East half a mile, when we landed
quoteLast: and encamped.  During the greatest part of the distance we came to-day, the river runs close under the mountains on the left.

quoteLast: for those of the officers and patients who wished to attend. After this service the other patients came in for morning prayers, at which the Bishop said a few words to them.

quoteFirst: Supper was ordered for Mr. Stewart at half-past
quoteLast: ; and this meal Sir Nicholas had consented should be laid downstairs in his own private room opening out of the hall, and that he and his ladies should sit down to table at the same time. Mr. Stewart went to his room an hour before to dress for riding, and to superintend the packing of his saddle-bags; and at half-past seven he was conducted downstairs by Sir Nicholas who insisted on carrying the saddle-bags with his own hands, and they found the two ladies waiting for them in the panelled study that had one window giving upon the terrace that ran along the south of the house
title: By What Authority?
author: Benson, Robert Hugh, 1871-1914

quoteFirst: Our progress down the Heiberg Glacier did not encounter any obstructions; only at the transition from the glacier to the Barrier were there a few crevasses that had to be circumvented.
quoteLast: on January 6 we halted at the angle of land that forms the entrance to the Heiberg Glacier, and thence extends northward. We had not yet recognized any of the land we lay under, but that was quite natural, as we now saw it from the opposite side.
title: The South Pole; an account of the Norwegian antarctic expedition in the "Fram," 1910-1912 — Volume 2
author: Amundsen, Roald, 1872-1928; Chater, Arthur G. (Arthur Grosvenor), 1866-1951 [Translator]

quoteFirst: Sound after ducks.  Back in a week.  Start
quoteLast: to-morrow morning.  Stay and put up here, and get off with me.  Oh!  I forgot. You 're one of those married men.
title: Avery
author: Phelps, Elizabeth Stuart, 1844-1911

quoteFirst: I breakfasted in a leisurely style
quoteLast: , without at all feeling that my loins were girded, and my staff in my hand. The head waiter, a very incarnation of good nature and harmless vanity, availed himself of the opportunity for trying to persuade me to delay my departure till the evening, or still better till to-morrow, that I might see General von Göben, who, as he impressively informed me, was to arrive to-day with a party of seven, and had taken the whole of the first floor.
title: A walk in the Grisons
author: Zincke, F. Barham (Foster Barham), 1817-1893

quoteLast: ,” therefore, had more than the usual significance, for it was known to imply a concert in the superbly appointed music hall, by singers from the opera, and an exhibition of paintings in the new gallery, so spacious that it ran from block to block, such a one as had never before been seen in any private dwelling in Manhattan.
title: At the Sign of the Fox: A Romance

quoteFirst: "My brother saw you.  They were coming back from Salterne in the yawl, and passed under the Beak about
quoteLast: .  They thought it was _I_, you see," Pamela made a little grimace of disgust, "and said what was I doing there? I said I wasn’t there."

quoteFirst: The fatal intimation of his bankruptcy, however, awaited him at home, and next morning early I was surprised by a verbal message to come to him as soon as I had got up. Fearful that he had got a fresh attack of the complaint from which he had now for some years been free, or that he had been involved in some quarrel, I went to see him by
quoteLast: , and found him already by candle-light seated at his writing-table, surrounded by papers which he was examining, holding out his hand to me as I entered, he said, "Skene, this is the hand of a beggar. Constable has failed, and I am ruined _de fond en comble_.
title:
The Journal of Sir Walter Scott
From the Original Manuscript at Abbotsford
author: Scott, Walter, 1771-1832; Douglas, David, 1823-1916 [Editor]
